stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on implementing a duel minigame against the character Boshi. The stream focused on creating a cinematic countdown sequence, troubleshooting camera angles, and solving the technical challenge of attaching a gun model to Mario's hand. He also discussed project status, his history with Nintendo takedowns, and fixed bugs related to character rigging and animations.

development_findings.summary: The primary focus of the stream was developing the 'Boshi Duel' minigame, including programming the countdown, animations, camera cuts, and preparing to add Mario's weapon.
development_findings.quote: I think next up we should program the egg that he throws.

development_findings.summary: Kaze confirms the game's overworld currently crashes when running on original N64 hardware, though individual levels seem to work better. This is a known issue the team needs to fix.
development_findings.quote: The overworld is really wrong right now. Maybe one day it will work. Today is not today.

development_findings.summary: A significant technical challenge was attaching a gun to Mario's hand performantly. The solution involves rendering a second, invisible Mario model that shares the same animation data, with only the gun model attached to its hand being visible.
development_findings.quote: I can see the vision now of copying Mario's rig and attaching the gun to just his hand and then rendering an invisible Mario with only the hand visible where the hand is the gun. You seeing my vision here? It would work. I'm doing that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze explains a core limitation of the SM64 engine: animations are based purely on rotations, not translations. This complicates actions like throwing objects, which must be manually coded.
development_findings.quote: Animations do not have translation in Mario 64 except for the first one... It's all just rotations.

development_findings.summary: Based on a fan suggestion, Kaze decides to implement a redemption arc for Boshi, where after being defeated, he will reappear elsewhere to offer a reaction time challenge for fun, demonstrating how community feedback directly influences game content.
development_findings.quote: I'm thinking make the penguins reappear in later levels again if you have freed them... Boshi, I like this idea and I will make for bonus content.

development_findings.summary: Kaze provides a project status update, stating that only three levels are left to be made and that the project is in its 'last fifth', though he estimates it will still take months to complete, aiming for a release before 2026.
development_findings.quote: Do you guys actually realize how crazy it is how close we're done to being done? Like only three levels are missing... It's the last fifth of the game.

development_findings.summary: Kaze dismisses using code from Mario Kart 64 for a potential racing level, citing that fellow developer Fazan has told him about the 'horrors' of that game's code.
development_findings.quote: I want nothing to do with that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze shares fun facts about obscure, long-term bugs in the original Super Mario 64 that only manifest after extreme wait times, such as the star menu breaking after over two years.
development_findings.quote: The star menu stops working for two years and three months if you wait on the menu... the diadox painting stops rippling after a week or so.

context_findings.summary: Kaze discusses his history with Nintendo DMCA takedowns, noting they've taken down ~70 of his videos, including non-Mario content like Blender tutorials. He plans to release a 'copyright-free' version of the game's trailer in anticipation of a takedown and is strategically planning the release to avoid clashing with a major Nintendo launch.
context_findings.quote: A lot of people tell me that they're worried that this game is going to get taken down by Nintendo but I never understood what they think that would look like. Like how would this go down? Would Nintendo come to my house and like delete it off my pc?

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses his personal design philosophies, including his preference for playing games that are different from each other, his critique of RPG gameplay mechanics, and his dislike for low-brow humor like fart jokes.
context_findings.quote: I think it's good to like your own work.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals his practical approach to software, stating he doesn't update tools like emulators unless he encounters a specific bug, preferring stability over new features.
context_findings.quote: I don't update software unless I have a bug with the software.

context_findings.summary: Kaze receives unsolicited but potentially useful technical suggestions from his community, such as a new sine and cosine approximation emailed to him by a fan.
context_findings.quote: Dude, I got a random email today. And this email just said, 'please look at my sine and cos approximation.' And he just sent me two screenshots. And it's actually a pretty cool idea that he has.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions his wife, Zeina, is babysitting, providing a small glimpse into their work-life dynamic and his preference to be working on the game with her.
context_findings.quote: Can you believe Zeina's on babysitting instead of making games with me right now?

context_findings.summary: Kaze reflects on the impact of Nintendo's copyright actions on his channel's growth, believing he would have a significantly larger subscriber base without their interference.
context_findings.quote: I feel like without Nintendo's interference, I would have a million subs by now. No exaggeration. Maybe not a million. Maybe like 800,000.

context_findings.summary: Kaze reveals he has a business plan for his next original project, which includes a Kickstarter campaign that will be advertised alongside the release of 'Return to Yoshi's Island'.
context_findings.quote: I'm gonna bundle it together with the ad for my kickstarter for the game I'm gonna make after I'm done with return to yoshi's islands so it's all gonna work out i i have the advertising plan down.

biobak.summary: Biobak is present in the stream chat, and Kaze mentions that Biobak typically reviews and improves his 3D models after Kaze creates the initial versions.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions his wife Zeina is babysitting and will be making pizza, showing their personal life dynamic outside of direct game development collaboration.
zeina.quote: I'm gonna have my wife make a pizza for me tonight. Aren't I living the best life?

key_stories.title: The Duel Countdown Implementation
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to create an effective countdown for the Boshi duel. After failed attempts with HUD elements and in-world text that looked bad, he opted to create a more cinematic, scripted cutscene to control the presentation and timing perfectly.
key_stories.challenge: How to implement a compelling and good-looking countdown for the Boshi duel minigame.
key_stories.process: Kaze first considered a simple HUD text countdown but felt it was hard to program and lacked expression. He drew inspiration from Mario Party and Kirby Samurai minigames. After trying to render numbers in world space and finding it looked awful, he pivoted to creating a multi-shot cutscene focusing on Boshi, then Mario, before the 'Fire' signal.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to scrap the HUD and in-world text ideas in favor of a full, non-interactive cutscene. This approach gives him full control over camera angles, character focus, and timing, resulting in a more cinematic and polished player experience.
key_stories.key_quote: I am not a fan of the 321. I'll tell it to you as it is. It does not look good. We need a better idea here.

key_stories.title: Attaching the Gun with an Invisible Mario
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to attach a gun to Mario's hand, but the engine doesn't easily expose hand position data. After technical discussion, he implemented a creative and performant solution: rendering an invisible copy of Mario's rig with the gun attached to its hand, ensuring it moves correctly without expensive calculations.
key_stories.challenge: How to attach a gun model to Mario's hand in a performant way that works within the SM64 engine's limitations.
key_stories.process: Kaze initially struggled with how to get the gun to follow Mario's hand animation. The engine doesn't persist hand matrix data in a way that's easy to read. After a discussion with Lilaa in chat, he devised a clever workaround: copying Mario's entire rig, making it invisible, attaching the gun to its hand, and rendering it.
key_stories.outcome: The final solution was to spawn a second, invisible Mario object that perfectly mirrors the player's animations. The gun model is attached to this invisible rig's hand, allowing it to move correctly with Mario without the performance cost of capturing and reapplying matrix data every frame.
key_stories.key_quote: The problem is Mario's hand position never exists. All that exists is Mario's hand matrix. And it only exists for one blink of time in like a weird state where you can't really read it.

key_stories.title: Rewriting the Save State Raps
key_stories.summary: While reviewing text, Kaze and his chat rediscovered the cringey raps for the anti-save-state Yoshi. A viewer with a literature background offered to rewrite them, and Kaze accepted, turning a moment of critique into a direct community collaboration.
key_stories.challenge: The in-game raps for the anti-save-state Yoshi character are considered cringey and use forced rhymes ('Zweigreime').
key_stories.process: While reviewing game text, Kaze came across the old anti-save-state raps. He read them aloud, and the chat reacted negatively, calling them cringe. Kaze defended them playfully, but when a user offered to write better versions, he immediately accepted the help.
key_stories.outcome: A chatter in the stream, who is studying literature, offered to rewrite the raps. Kaze was open to the idea and asked them to send the new rhymes via Discord, creating a spontaneous collaboration to improve the game's writing.
key_stories.key_quote: What? They're nice. Don't disagree in the timeline. Such an attack is not fine. Your save states are rude. They ruin my mood. So listen up, dude. I have a feud.
